messageBody:
## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for December 20, 2017 - December 26, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-12-27T22:15:46Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-12-20T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-12-26T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20171227-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:


Solar activity was at very low levels during this reporting period with no significant flares or CMEs.
 
Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period. The highest values of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic period of 2017-12-26T18:00Z-21:00Z. This increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with a small coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2017-12-24. The solar wind speed reached values of >550 km/s on 2017-12-24. 

STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2017-12-21. The solar wind speed reached values of ~650 km/s between 2017-12-23 and 2017-12-24.

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed 
## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-12-27T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2018-01-02T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. There is only one small active regions currently visible on the solar disk that could produce some flare or CME activity. An increase in geomagnetic activity is expected around 2017-12-31 due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream originating from the low latitude extension of the northern coronal hole seen at the northeast on the Earth's facing solar disk around 2017-12-27.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score


NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for December 13, 2017 - December 19, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-12-20T20:57:22Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-12-13T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-12-19T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20171220-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at very low levels during this reporting period with no significant flares or CMEs.

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period. The highest values of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2017-12-17T06:00Z-09:00Z and 2017-12-17T18:00Z-21:00Z. This increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with a small coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2017-12-16. The solar wind speed reached values of 600-650 km/s on 2017-12-17 and 2017-12-18. 

STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2017-12-14. The solar wind speed reached values of ~550-600 km/s between 2017-12-14 and 2017-12-16.

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2017-12-18T08:35Z. These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 were associated with the coronal hole high speed stream described above (see notifications 20171218-AL-001 and 20171218-AL-002).  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron flux on the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-12-20T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-12-26T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. There are two small active regions currently visible at the Earth's facing solar disk that could produce some flare or CME activity.  Increase in geomagnetic activity is expected around 2017-12-25 due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream originating from a low latitude coronal hole seen in SDO images close to disk center on 2017-12-20.



## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score


NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-12-18T13:14:54Z
## Message ID: 20171218-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is above 10^5 pfu starting at 2017-12-18T08:35Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2017-12-16T21:17Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2017-12-18T08:35:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for December 06, 2017 - December 12, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-12-14T00:11:02Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-12-06T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-12-12T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20171214-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at very low levels during this reporting period with no significant flares or CMEs.

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period. The highest values of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2017-12-06T03:00z-06:00Z and 2017-12-12T18:00Z-21:00Z. The slight increase in geomagnetic activity on 2017-12-12 was associated with a small coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2017-12-11. The solar wind speed reached values of >500 km/s on 2017-12-12. 

STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2017-12-07. The solar wind speed reached values of ~600 km/s on 2017-12-08.

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  


CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-12-13T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-12-19T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity are expected to be low for the upcoming week. There are several small or decayed active regions present on the solar disk that have some potential for flares or CMEs. Increase in geomagnetic activity is expected around 2017-12-16 due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream originating from a coronal hole seen in SDO images close to disk center on 2017-12-13.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for November 29, 2017 - December 05, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-12-06T18:17:04Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-11-29T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-12-05T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20171206-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at very low levels during this reporting period with no major flares or CMEs.

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period. The highest values of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2017-12-05T09:00Z to 2017-12-05T15:00Z. This increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2017-12-04. The solar wind speed reached values of ~600 km/s on 2017-12-05 and 2017-12-06. Another small coronal hole high speed stream was detected earlier by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2017-11-30 where the solar wind speed reached values of ~500 km/s on 2017-11-30 and 2017-12-01. 
  
STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2017-12-02. The solar wind speed reached values of ~550 km/s on 2017-12-03.

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-12-06T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-12-12T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.  Two small active regions are currently present on the solar disk both on the STEREO A facing side of the sun that have some potential for flares or CMEs. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux at the Earth's outer radiation belt may increase in the next few days due to the coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2017-12-05.


## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score
